awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Tuning passive prosthetic leg dynamics to create low-cost, robust devices that can replicate physiological gait in multiple activities of daily living
awd_abstract_narration:
Proposal #: 1653758
PI: Winter, Amos

The aim of this CAREER project is to characterize the dynamics of prosthetic legs that utilize only passive mechanical elements (e.g. no motors or electronic controllers) such that it is possible to tune their performance to generate desired walking behavior in multiple activities of daily living. The project focuses on full leg prostheses, suitable for individuals with above-knee amputations.  The goal is to understand how prosthetic dynamics vary based on the mass, geometry, and stiffness of the components of a passive prosthetic and how these can be varied to accurately replicate ablebodied walking.  Combining this theoretical study, and adapting it to multiple activities of daily living, will result in the design of high-performance, low-cost prosthetic limbs that drastically enhance the mobility and quality of life for persons with lower-limb amputation in developing countries, while also providing a cost effective option with enhanced function for users of passive prostheses in developed countries. The core intellectual merit of this program is the creation of knowledge that connects the mechanical design of prosthetic legs to the biomechanical performance they induce. This knowledge will enable prosthetists to better customize limbs to patients? body size, weight, and lifestyle. The educational and outreach activities of this CAREER project will include teaching graduate, undergraduate, and high school students about the challenges faced by people with disabilities throughout the world, and how science and engineering can be used to make a fundamental impact on their lives. These students will directly contribute to the design of assistive devices, including the prosthetic legs created under this award. This CAREER program was designed to create the broadest possible impact on lower-limb prosthesis users by delivering high-performance legs that are affordable and appropriate in developing and developed countries. 

The aim of this CAREER project is to characterize the dynamics of prosthetic legs that utilize only passive mechanical elements, in order to tune their performance to generate desired kinematics and kinetics in multiple activities of daily living. This will create fundamental engineering knowledge that correlates the mechanical design of prosthetic legs to the biomechanical performance they induce, and will enable prosthetists to better customize limbs to patients? body size, weight, and lifestyle. The proposed research will manifest in high-performance, low-cost, robust, purely mechanical prosthetic legs. Functionality of the limbs will be enhanced by measuring able-bodied kinematics and kinetics from common activities of daily living, and then using these as targets in predictive models of how joint torques required for able-bodied motion can be produced with passive mechanical elements. This research program will build a foundational understanding of: how joint torque should vary as a function of leg segment mass to produce desired kinematics; how these adjusted joint torque profiles can be induced using passive mechanical elements; and how the stiffness and geometry of passive prosthetic feet can be tuned to accurately replicate physiological gait. For the first time, this work will be done for full leg prostheses appropriate for above-knee amputees.  The technology resulting from this award will drastically enhance mobility and quality of life for amputees in developing countries, while also providing a cost effective option with enhanced function for users of passive prostheses in developed countries.   The education and outreach activities of this program involve high school, undergraduate, and graduate students in design projects for individuals with disabilities from developing countries.  This will improve students understanding of the importance of needs analysis while also supporting efforts to attract underrepresented groups to STEM fields.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this project was to understand and characterize the operation of prosthetic legs for above-knee amputees. Using this characterization, we designed a low-cost prosthetic leg for people living in low- and middle- income countries that would lead to high-performance and satisfy user requirements. In the case of this project, high-performance is defined as providing stability on uneven terrain and promoting able-bodied motion. The latter not only improves the mobility of prostheses users, but also helps to prevent socioeconomical stigma from being perceived as an amputee. The low-cost requirement was addressed by considering materials, ease of manufacturing and assembly for the future product to be distributable by a non-profit organization in India, Bhagwan Mahaveer Viklang Sahayata Samiti (a.k.a. “Jaipur Foot” organization). As a result of this project, we have created multiple methods for designing both prosthetic feet and prosthetic knees for above-knee amputees. Specifically, we have created a method for designing and evaluating prosthetic feet for above-knee amputees, a method to select recommended damping for a knee mechanism, and a framework to design prosthetic feet and knee together. These concepts and frameworks can be extended to high- income countries as well.

To assist in our design and theory, we have collected motion and force data from ten able-bodied subjects walking at different paces, up and down ramps and stairs. These data were used as the target reference data for our designs. We also conducted a pilot study to understand what people perceived as typical to set the range of acceptable performances.

The prosthetic foot design and performance evaluation method, Hip Trajectory Error (HTE), customizes a prosthetic foot for an individual based on their height, foot length, and body mass. The HTE framework accounts for walking deviations common for above-knee amputees, such as lack of knee flexion right after heel strike. The HTE feet, after short acclimation period, have experimentally shown the same performance as the participant’s daily-use prescribed prosthetic feet that required careful tuning and selection. Walking performance of HTE feet was also compared to high-performance below-knee amputee prosthetic feet, customized to participants’ body characteristics using Lower Leg Trajectory Error (LLTE) design framework. The LLTE framework has been previously created and experimentally validated for designing prosthetic feet for below-knee amputee, showing high-performance in comparison to commonly available prosthetic carbon fiber feet for below knee amputees. LLTE feet are designed to promote able-bodied motion of the lower leg , leg segment connecting the ankle and the knee. Since unlike below-knee amputee, above-knee amputees do not flex their knee after heel strike, HTE feet enabled improved walking performance over LLTE feet, experimentally demonstrating the importance of designing prosthetic feet for above-knee amputees’ unique mobility needs.

The resulting prosthetic knee design is a fully passive mechanism that uses a locking system to provide stability and allow for knee flexion when the foot is off the ground. The flexion motion is controlled by hydraulic dampers, that change the resistance based on the speed at which the user is walking. A damping experimental study demonstrated how amputee gait changes with damping and evaluated the performance of a damping methodology that considers unique aspects of amputee gait. Based on inconclusive results in predicting optimal damping, the model was updated to include the interaction with the foot and optimize the performance of the entire leg. Additionally, the prototype design of the entire leg has been updated and analyzed for mass manufacturing. These changes will allow the final product to be easily sourced and manufactured in the target markets.

Through this project, we created a prosthetic leg design that will allow people in low- and middle-income countries to achieve stable gait with close to able bodied motion. This walking motion improvement could potentially decrease societal consequences due to stigma against amputation.  Additionally, we have investigated how changes in the passive components in the prosthetic leg design affect amputee mobility. These characterizations can be used for any lower limb prosthesis design to achieve target biomechanical performance.

 


Last Modified: 01/16/2024
Modified by: Amos Winter
